content: Recent events have renewed congressional interest in safe management of spent nuclear fuel and high-level nuclear waste. The report focuses on the current situation with spent nuclear fuel storage in the United States, primarily at current and former reactor facilities for the foreseeable future. No nation has established a permanent disposal repository for high-level radioactive waste yet. In the United States, the debate over a disposal repository for high-level radioactive waste, including SNF, has been ongoing for decades. The proposed Yucca Mountain repository was terminated in 2009, leading to uncertainty over long-term storage solutions. Key issues include strategies for interim SNF storage, location of storage facilities, and management structures. The Blue Ribbon Commission's report has sparked a renewed debate on these topics. The Blue Ribbon Commission on America's Nuclear Future released its final report in January 2012, modifying a draft from July 2011 after extensive public testimony. Debates include safety concerns, with some advocating for wider use of dry storage methods. Cost and investment impacts are also considered, with recommendations for interim centralized storage at a volunteer location. Some recommend limited consolidation of interim SNF storage at existing operational reactor sites, using wet pool and dry cask storage technologies. Senator Dianne Feinstein emphasizes the need to rethink spent fuel management, transitioning from pools to dry cask storage after 5-7 years. In California, fuel assemblies are re-racked in wet spent fuel pools for long-term storage. Reports from Japan show no issues with dry cask storage at Dai-ichi, prompting consideration for quicker movement of spent fuel to dry cask storage.
